p:
We found that only a small portion of infections was reported (2.85–19.99%) as suspected cases across the islands (Table 2). This indicates that actual epidemic size could be quite larger than the documented epidemic size. Those non-reported zika infections might be either asymptomatic infections and/or infections with mild symptoms that did not enter the healthcare system. This phenomenon was supported by the household survey following the Yap island outbreak in 2007
9 . Having a large number of non-reported cases estimated in this study warns higher severity of zika burden in epidemic regions and underscores a need for better surveillance and detection strategies.
